title: 103_hr1293
content: The "Welfare and Teenage Pregnancy Reduction Act" authorizes block grants to states for families with dependent children under Part A of title IV of the Social Security Act. States meeting the requirements are entitled to grants equal to 103 percent of Federal outlays under part A for fiscal year 1992. Application requirements are outlined in the Act. The Act outlines application requirements for states to receive grants to assist families with dependent children. States meeting the requirements are entitled to block grants equal to 103 percent of Federal outlays under part A for fiscal year 1992. Each State receiving a grant under section 403 must use it to assist families with dependent children. The State cannot use the funds to provide assistance for a dependent child if the parent is under 18 years old or if paternity/maternity is not established. Additionally, a State can provide assistance for up to 1 year when a family with a dependent child moves from another State. When a dependent child moves from another State, the receiving State can either apply its own rules for assistance or treat the child as the original State would have. The definition of a dependent child is outlined in Section 405. The term 'dependent child' refers to an individual who is needy, deprived of parental support, living with certain relatives, and either under 18 years old or as determined by the State. The term 'dependent child' includes individuals under 19 years old who are full-time students in secondary school or vocational training. "SEC. 406. ANNUAL REPORTS." The State must submit an annual report to the Secretary within 6 months of the end of each fiscal year for which a grant is received. The report should include the average number of families with dependent children, changes in teen pregnancies, births of children eligible for assistance, and termination of assistance due to gainful employment. The State must submit an annual report to the Secretary within 6 months of the end of each fiscal year for which a grant is received. The report should include the average number of families with dependent children, changes in teen pregnancies, births of children eligible for assistance, termination of assistance due to gainful employment, and the evaluation of the State's progress in meeting grant application goals. "SEC. 407. WITHHOLDING OF BLOCK GRANT." Beginning 4 years after the effective date of this part, the Secretary may suspend or withhold part or all of a grant to a State if the State program of assistance to families with dependent children has not adequately met their needs. The amendment made by subsection (a) will take effect on October 1, 1993. References in other laws to part A of title IV of the Social Security Act will be considered as references to the relevant provisions. References to part A of title IV of the Social Security Act before October 1, 1993, will be considered as references to the relevant provisions. Reduction of federal AFDC administrative costs. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must ensure that administrative costs for the program in part A of title IV of the Social Security Act do not exceed 50% of the total costs for fiscal year 1992. A report must be submitted to Congress within one year detailing actions taken to comply with this requirement. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must report to Congress within one year detailing the actions taken to ensure that administrative costs for the program do not exceed 50% of total costs for fiscal year 1992. This report should include the reasons for each action, anticipated savings, and the methodologies used for any computations.
